modules.description: This module implements a Naive Bayes classifier for categorical data, providing functions to train a model from labeled samples and evaluate class probabilities for new features. It works with discrete class and feature types, computing prior and likelihood probabilities per class using optional smoothing. Concrete use cases include text classification, spam filtering, or categorizing data with predefined discrete attributes.

Implements cubic spline interpolation for numerical data arrays. It constructs piecewise polynomial functions from point sets with optional boundary conditions, returning interpolated values at arbitrary points. Fits models to tabulated data for smoothing or evaluating derivatives in scientific computing tasks.

This module implements basic mutable array operations for floating-point numbers, including creation, indexing, and element assignment. It works directly with the `floatarray` type, enabling efficient storage and manipulation of numerical data. Use this module for tasks like numerical computations, statistical processing, or machine learning algorithms that require high-performance array handling.

Solves and evaluates tridiagonal systems using specialized linear algebra operations. Works with arrays of float triplets representing diagonals and float arrays for vectors. Enables efficient interpolation and smoothing over structured data grids.

This module implements a binomial Naive Bayes classifier for categorical data encoded with dummy variables. It provides functions to train a model from labeled samples, evaluate class probabilities for new features, and extract learned probabilities per class. It works with features represented as arrays of floats and classes defined by the underlying data module.

This module implements sampling algorithms for generating values from discrete distributions. It supports uniform sampling over a finite set, categorical sampling with weighted probabilities, and softmax sampling with temperature scaling. These functions are used to simulate random draws from predefined domains, such as selecting actions in reinforcement learning or generating synthetic data with specified distributions.

This module implements standard matrix operations including addition, subtraction, scalar multiplication, matrix multiplication, and transposition. It works with matrices represented as arrays of vectors and supports operations like extracting rows or columns, checking equality with a tolerance, and creating diagonal or identity matrices. Concrete use cases include solving systems of linear equations, performing linear transformations, and computing inner products in numerical computations.

This module offers descriptive statistical operations on numerical datasets, including measures of central tendency (mean, median, geometric mean), dispersion (variance, standard deviation), and distribution shape (skewness, kurtosis). It supports analysis of associations through covariance, correlation (Pearson and Spearman), and cosine similarity, while providing utilities for dataset summarization and histogram generation with customizable binning strategies. These tools are suited for data exploration, hypothesis testing, and preprocessing in statistical modeling or machine learning workflows.

Implements incremental statistical computations using recurrence relations, allowing efficient updates and merging of running statistics. It operates on a state type `Oml.Online.t` that tracks summary metrics like mean, variance, and count as new data points are added. This module is useful for real-time data analysis where statistics must be maintained over streaming or batch data without recomputing from scratch.

Implements numerical root-finding methods using the secant and second-order Newton-Raphson algorithms. Operates on univariate real-valued functions represented as `float -> float`. Useful for solving equations like `f(x) = 0` in mathematical modeling or optimization problems where analytical derivatives are unavailable.

This module calculates Kullback-Leibler divergence between normal and discrete distributions. It provides `normal_kl_divergence` for comparing Gaussian distributions using their means and standard deviations, and `discrete_kl_divergence` for categorical distributions represented as labeled probability pairs. These functions are used in model comparison, information theory, and machine learning to quantify distributional differences.

This module implements sampling algorithms for generating values from discrete distributions. It supports uniform sampling over a finite set, categorical sampling with weighted probabilities, and softmax sampling with temperature scaling. These functions are used to simulate random draws from predefined domains, such as selecting actions in reinforcement learning or generating synthetic data with specified distributions.

Implements Kahan summation algorithm to reduce numerical error in floating-point summation. Tracks cumulative sums with compensation terms to correct rounding errors during repeated additions. Useful for high-precision numerical computations where naive summation would lose accuracy due to floating-point drift.

This module provides functional list traversal, transformation, and structural analysis operations, including indexed mapping, predicate-based filtering, folding with accumulator threading, and comparison-driven sorting/merging. It works with generic `'a list` values and associative (key-value) lists, supporting use cases like data pipeline transformations, algorithmic list reductions, and ordered sequence manipulations. Specific patterns include element-wise computation with index awareness, conditional list partitioning, and efficient sorted list merging with customizable comparison logic.

This module offers array creation, transformation, and manipulation operations, including in-place updates, slicing, folding, and sorting, alongside statistical functions like ranking and binary search. It supports generic arrays (`'a array`) and optimized mutable float arrays, enabling efficient numerical computations and sequence processing. These tools are suited for tasks such as data preprocessing, algorithm implementation, and statistical analysis where array-based data structures require transformation, aggregation, or randomization.

Implements linear regression for modeling the relationship between a single input variable and a response variable using arrays of floats. Provides functions to fit a model, evaluate predictions, and compute statistical metrics like residuals, coefficients, R-squared, and F-statistic. Designed for numerical analysis tasks such as trend analysis, calibration, and empirical modeling from scientific or financial data.

Implements Naive Bayes classifiers for categorical and binomial data. Provides training functions to compute class priors and feature likelihoods, and evaluation functions to predict class probabilities from feature vectors. Used for text classification, spam detection, and categorical data analysis with discrete features and classes.

Performs interpolation using linear, spline, and tridiagonal methods. Handles float pairs, arrays of triplets for diagonals, and data points for cubic splines. Used to model numerical relationships, smooth data grids, and compute derivatives in scientific contexts.

This module defines core operations for fitting and evaluating linear regression models, including parameter estimation via ordinary least squares and prediction on new data. It works with numerical datasets represented as matrices and vectors, supporting both single and multi-variable regression tasks. Concrete use cases include modeling housing prices based on features like size and location, or analyzing trends in time-series data.

This module defines input interfaces for classification tasks, specifying required operations for handling encoded data. It works with categorical, continuous, and dummy-encoded data structures, ensuring consistent access to features and labels. Concrete use cases include loading training data for classifiers and preprocessing input for model evaluation.

Performs vector arithmetic on float arrays, including addition, subtraction, scalar multiplication, and dot product. Supports element-wise operations and comparisons with a tolerance for floating-point differences. Useful for numerical computations in machine learning, physics simulations, and statistical analysis.

This module evaluates continued fractions using recursive algorithms, supporting custom functions for generating coefficients. It works with a state type `t` encapsulating coefficient generation logic, and produces numerical results given a starting value. Concrete use cases include computing special mathematical functions like Bessel or hypergeometric functions through their continued fraction representations.

This module defines core interfaces for classification models, including functions for training on labeled datasets, predicting class labels, and evaluating model performance. It operates on feature vectors and label types, supporting supervised learning workflows. Concrete use cases include implementing classification algorithms like logistic regression or decision trees.

Implements mathematical operations for statistical modeling, including softmax normalization with optional temperature scaling. Operates on float arrays to produce probability distributions, commonly used in classification and neural network output layers. Directly supports tasks like converting raw model scores into probabilities for multi-class prediction problems.

This module evaluates classification model performance using binary prediction data. It calculates metrics like sensitivity, specificity, and AUC from predicted/actual pairs. Use it to assess model quality on labeled test data or compute cross-validated AUC from score-label pairs.

Stores and manipulates probability distributions over labeled classes. Provides functions to compute, update, and query class probabilities. Used to determine the most probable class label from a set of predictions in classification tasks.

This module defines basic arithmetic operations for floating-point numbers, including addition, subtraction, multiplication, and division. It works directly with the `float` type and is used for numerical computations requiring precision. Concrete use cases include statistical calculations, machine learning algorithms, and scientific simulations where floating-point arithmetic is essential.

This module implements numerical root-finding algorithms including Newton-Raphson and bisection methods. It operates on floating-point functions and intervals, requiring target functions and optional derivatives. Concrete use cases include solving nonlinear equations in mathematical modeling and optimization problems where analytical solutions are intractable.

This module provides statistical inference and parameter estimation capabilities. It works with numerical data types, probability distributions, and labeled datasets to support concrete tasks like computing confidence intervals, estimating distribution parameters from sample data, and performing hypothesis tests. Use cases include analyzing experimental results, fitting statistical models to observed data, and quantifying uncertainty in machine learning predictions.

This module classifies data into labeled categories using probabilistic models and feature-based prediction. It supports operations for training classifiers, computing class probabilities, and evaluating model accuracy with metrics like AUC and sensitivity. It works with categorical, continuous, and encoded feature data, enabling use cases such as spam detection, text categorization, and supervised learning with discrete outcomes.

This module defines core numerical constants, array/list utilities, and floating-point comparison operations. It provides functions for checking value bounds, handling invalid arguments, and managing convergence failures in iterative processes. Use cases include numerical algorithm validation, array boundary checks, and precise floating-point equality testing in statistical or machine learning computations.

This module groups numerical methods for root-finding, vector and matrix arithmetic, and function estimation. It operates on floating-point functions, float arrays, and matrices to solve nonlinear equations, perform linear algebra operations, and compute numerical derivatives. Concrete use cases include implementing gradient-based optimizations, simulating physical systems with linear transformations, and numerically solving equations in statistical models.

This module implements linear and spline-based interpolation techniques for numerical data modeling. It operates on arrays of float pairs for linear interpolation, arrays of triplets for tridiagonal systems, and sorted data points for cubic spline interpolation. Use cases include smoothing irregular data grids, computing derivatives of empirical data in physics simulations, and filling missing values in financial time series.

Maintains running statistics using recurrence relations to efficiently update metrics like mean, variance, and count as new data points arrive. It works with a state type `t` that stores aggregated values including sum, sum of squares, min, and max. Useful for real-time analytics on streaming data or incremental batch processing where full recomputation is impractical.

This module provides numerical methods for statistical analysis, machine learning, and mathematical computation. It works with floats, arrays, matrices, and labeled datasets to support concrete tasks like hypothesis testing, regression modeling, classification, and real-time metric tracking. Use cases include training probabilistic classifiers, estimating parameters from empirical data, and solving nonlinear equations in scientific computing.
